Is it 100% required to have a degree to get into the game design field? Or any position at Riot? Always thought it would be amazing dream come true to work at the company of the game I have played for a number of years. Not to mention the roughly 6000 hours I have on here.

I can't speak to the game design field, but I am a Rioter, and I don't have a college degree. I was in the game industry and worked my way up through Customer Service at another company for a significant time, so my network and experience helped me snag Riot's attention when I applied to Player Support.  

A degree is a good way to show experience and dedication, but there are others. A strong portfolio, having documented related field work, things like that can make up for a lot. It takes more than just loving the game, you have to really be ready to show your skill set professionally, and that's why college works well because it's built in documentation of a direction and drive, however I don't think it's the only way to show these things.

So while having a degree of some sort is the standard or normal path, it's not the only one into Riot.

You don't need a degree in game design to work at RIOT. The amount of time you've played the game is helpful but it depends on what you can demonstrate you've learned in that time, not just the raw time itself that would help you there.

If you don't have a degree, relevant experience is as good if not better.  Too often I see companies with arbitrary requirements.  I can't speak for Riot's policies, but they seem like a company that would value experience.  It's about what you bring to the table and if you're a good fit, not so much your credentials.

This article also made me think about why I ended up going into Game Design. I had been a Music Technology major (my other passion) for years, and about a year and a half ago I switched to Computer Science with a focus in Game Design, and I'm loving it. I originally wanted to do songs/themes for games, but got into the knitty-gritty of Music Tech and found that it wasn't going in the direction I wanted, so I switched, and found out I enjoy creating games more. I'm working on my last few classes (got 6 left :D) so be on the lookout for me Riot, I'll be swinging by with an application soon!

Yes and yes. To all y'all who are worried about things like college/uni and about choosing your life direction, don't fret. Try things out. See what you like and don't like. Talk with counselors and people out there who are willing to listen and help. Have fun, and give it your all. :)

Although I love the fact that Championship Riven is coming back, I think that taking off the on hit animation for the q and reverting it to the classic green Riven cast was a bit far (based off the video from the SkinSpotlights Youtube channel). It throws off the color scheme and makes the skin feel a bit less like a true championship skin and more like a mix of one and a regular skin. Although the Thresh and Shyvana skins were consistantly re-released and weren't the same kind of legacy skin that Championship Riven is, the particles and design didn't change much for them, and they feel like genuinely great skins as a result. I get that you want to make sure that the original owners are rewarded for having played the game when the skin was originally released, but I think that a custom loading screen card as well as the extra ult particles and the added crown is enough. All that being said, I didn't initially own the skin, so maybe I'm biased.
